case_name: Mugneeram Bangur and Company v. Gurbachan Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 180 of 1962 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 180 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 28, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court from original Decree No. 226 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 28, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court from original Decree No. 226 of 1952.

facts.text: The appellant company had land divided into building plots under the Lake Colony Scheme by constructing roads and drains.

anchor.surface_text: land belonging to the appellant company which had been divided into building plots by them in pursuance of what is known as the Lake Colony Scheme, by constructing roads and drains.

facts.text: The plaintiff-respondent entered into contracts with the company for purchase of plots pursuant to public offers.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff-respondent was one of the various persons who had entered into contracts with the company for purchase of plots, in pursuance of the public offers made by the company.

facts.text: Respondent addressed a letter to the company willing to purchase plots Nos. New Nos. 245 and 246 and paid Rs. 202/- earnest money.

anchor.surface_text: This he did by addressing the following letter to the company and paying Rs. 202/- by way of earnest money. To Mugneeram Bangur and Company Land Department. Russa Road, South, Tollygunge, Calcutta.

facts.text: The letter from respondent was probably written on May 14, 1941, as company issued receipt on that date.

anchor.surface_text: The letter does not bear any date but probably it was written on May 14, 1941 which is the date on which the company issued a receipt in his favour.

facts.text: Different portions of the land covered by the scheme were requisitioned by Government between November 12, 1941 and July 25, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: Different portions of the land covered by the scheme were requisitioned by Government between November 12, 1941 and July 25, 1944.

facts.text: The plots which the respondent had contracted to purchase (Nos. 245 and 246) were requisitioned by Government on February 18, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The plots which the respondents had contracted to purchase are said to form part of the land which was requisitioned by virtue of an order made by the Government on February 18, 1944.

facts.text: Company sent a circular notice on December 24, 1943 to persons who had entered contracts, stating land requisitioned and offering options to cancel or complete.

anchor.surface_text: According to the company, on December 24, 1943, a circular notice was sent to all those persons who had entered into contracts for purchase of plots from them stating that a considerable portion...

facts.text: Circular stated agreement cancelled unless option exercised within one month: refund earnest or complete registration taking land as is.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances we have decided to treat the agreement as cancelled and give you the option of taking of the refund of the earnest money deposited by you within one month...

facts.text: Respondent's attorneys wrote to company on May 8, 1946 inquiring when possession could be delivered as government de-requisitioning.

anchor.surface_text: On May 8, 1946 the respondents attorneys, acting under instructions, wrote to the company saying that the respondent had learnt from the companys office...

facts.text: Company replied on May 29, 1946 stating agreement cancelled due to failure to exercise options in circular, earnest forfeited.

anchor.surface_text: In reply to that letter the company wrote on May 29, 1946 drawing his attention to their circular letter and said that by reason of the failure...

facts.text: Respondent's attorneys replied on June 13, 1946 stating no receipt of circular, demanding date for road completion.

anchor.surface_text: On June 13, 1946, the respondents attorneys expressed surprise at the companys reply and stated that the respondent had not received the circular...

facts.text: Present suit instituted by respondent on August 8, 1946 in the court of the Second Subordinate Judge at Alipore.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently the company did nothing with the result that the present suit was instituted by the respondent on August 8, 1946 in the court of the Second Subordinate Judge at Alipore.

facts.text: Company resisted suit on grounds of discharge by frustration and suit premature.

anchor.surface_text: The company resisted the suit on various grounds but only two are material for the purpose of this appeal...

facts.text: Suit was decreed by trial court (Decree No. 226 of 1952).

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 28, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court from original Decree No. 226 of 1952.

facts.text: Decree upheld by Calcutta High Court on January 28, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 28, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court...

facts.text: Company obtained special leave to appeal from Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: A certificate that the case was fit for appeal to this Court having been refused by the High Court the company sought and obtained from this court special leave to appeal.

facts.text: Development work of roads and drains was completed when appeal heard by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: But the fact remains that this work had been completed when the appeal was heard by the High Court.

facts.text: War was already on when parties entered into the contract.

anchor.surface_text: Another important thing that requires notice in this connection is that the war was already on, when the parties entered into the contract.

facts.text: Land was used by Government for military purposes.

anchor.surface_text: We were informed that the land was used by the Government for military purposes.

facts.text: Requisition order required owner to place land at disposal of Military Estates Officer from November 14, 1941 until six months after war.

anchor.surface_text: The actual order served upon the company, among other things, provides The owner occupier of the said land (a) shall place the said land at the disposal...

facts.text: Company lost possession and access to land due to requisition.

anchor.surface_text: In consequence of this order the company lost possession of the land and automatically lost access thereto.

facts.text: Courts below decreed suit for specific performance and upheld by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed and that decree was upheld by the High Court in appeal.

facts.text: Case relates to effect of requisitioning orders made by Government during last war.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, like Satyabrata Ghose v. Mugneeram Bangur Co. and another1 relates to the effect of requisitioning orders made by the Government during the last war under which they took possession of land...
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 28, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court from original Decree No. 226 of 1952.

concepts.interpretation: Discharge by frustration under S.56 applies to supervening impossibility or unlawfulness; temporary requisition during known war does not frustrate contract where no fixed time limit for performance.
concepts.unlisted_description: Contract to be void if performance becomes impossible or unlawful due to supervening events.

anchor.surface_text: s. 56 as well as those of s. 32 of the Contract Act.

concepts.interpretation: Distinguished from English law of implying terms; Indian Contract Act provisions govern frustration.

arguments.claim: Previous decision in Satyabrata Ghose binds this case on frustration

Courts below right in upholding claim for specific performance

holdings.text: This case would really appear to be covered by the decision of this Court to which we have referred at the outset... This is what was held by this Court in the earlier case and that decision binds us.

anchor.surface_text: This case would really appear to be covered by the decision of this Court to which we have referred at the outset. Mr. Sen, however, points out that the question as to whether the contract could be said to have been discharged because of the fact that its performance was rendered unlawful as a result of the requisitioning orders made by the Government which was sought to be raised before this Court in that case was not permitted to be raised by it and has been left open. He admits that certain observations made by this Court towards the concluding portion of the judgment would indicate that this Court was not prepared to accept the contention sought to be urged before it. But, Mr. Sen says that as the contention was not permitted to be raised, the observations of this Court could be said to have been made merely in passing and at best be regarded as a tentative expression of its views. We think Mr. Sen is right in the sense that the question has been actually left open by this Court. But even so, we will have to consider whether the grounds upon which the previous decision rests would not be relevant for consideration in connection with the argument advanced by Mr. Sen. In so far as discharge of contract by reason of frustration is concerned there is no question of implying a term in the contract a term fundamental for its performance, as is done by the courts in England because we have here the provisions of s. 56 as well as those of s. 32 of the Contract Act. This is what was held by this Court in the earlier case and that decision binds us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Previous Supreme Court decision in Satyabrata Ghose directly applies ss.56 and 32 Contract Act to frustration in identical requisition context and binds this court.

holdings.text: No doubt, a contract can be frustrated either because of supervening impossibility of performance or because performance has become unlawful by reason of circumstances for which neither of the parties was responsible... the mere fact that the performance of an essential term of the contract... did not have the effect of frustrating the contract.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, a contract can be frustrated either because of supervening impossibility of performance or because performance has become unlawful by reason of circumstances for which neither of the parties was responsible. In the earlier case this Court has held that where the performance of an essential condition of the contract has become impossible due to supervening circumstances the contract would be discharged. This Court has further held that the impossibility need not be an absolute one but it is sufficient if further performance becomes impracticable by some cause for which neither of the parties was responsible. It, however, held that the mere fact that the performance of an essential term of the contract that is to say, of undertaking development of the area under the scheme could not be undertaken because the land had been requisitioned, did not have the effect of frustrating the contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies ss.56/32: temporary requisition during war does not frustrate where performance of development term only temporarily impossible/impracticable; parties aware of war risks.

holdings.text: Thus, where the performance of a contract had been rendered unlawful by reason of some subsequent event the contract would stand discharged but such discharge will take place not necessarily from the date on which the further performance was rendered unlawful, unless further performance was rendered unlawful for all time.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporary or indeterminate unlawfulness does not discharge unless coincides with performance due date; short requisition (e.g. 1 month) clearly insufficient.

holdings.text: Here it is pointed out by Mr. Sen that the respondent had made time the essence of the contract but that only applies to the grant of conveyance after the completion of the roads and drains. As already pointed out, parties were wholly silent as to the time within which the roads and drains were to be completed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract text: time essence only for conveyance post-development; no time fixed for roads/drains.

holdings.text: According to Mr. Sen, however, where the parties have failed to specify in the contract time within which it has to be performed s. 46 of the Contract Act comes in and the parties may be presumed to have agreed that the contract will be performed within reasonable time... the parties when they entered into the contract, knew the prevailing circumstances and must have borne in mind the possibility that something like what actually happened may happen.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.46 reasonable time excludes war/requisition delays contemplated by parties aware of circumstances.

holdings.text: Thus, in our view it cannot be said that because of the requisitioning orders which had the effect of making the entry by or on behalf of the company on the land illegal during the subsistence of the period of requisitioning the contract stood discharged.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: temporary illegality + no fixed/due time + contemplated risks = no discharge under s.56.

holdings.text: The Court would in such a case be justified in taking notice of subsequent events in moulding its relief accordingly.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Development completed pre-High Court appeal; equity allows noticing events to mould relief.

holdings.text: In our judgment the courts below were right in upholding the respondents claim.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Frustration defenses rejected; specific performance appropriate.

anchor.surface_text: This case would really appear to be covered by the decision of this Court to which we have referred at the outset. Mr. Sen, however, points out that the question as to whether the contract could be said to have been discharged because of the fact that its performance was rendered unlawful as a result of the requisitioning orders made by the Government which was sought to be raised before this Court in that case was not permitted to be raised by it and has been left open. He admits that certain observations made by this Court towards the concluding portion of the judgment would indicate that this Court was not prepared to accept the contention sought to be urged before it. But, Mr. Sen says that as the contention was not permitted to be raised, the observations of this Court could be said to have been made merely in passing and at best be regarded as a tentative expression of its views. We think Mr. Sen is right in the sense that the question has been actually left open by this Court. But even so, we will have to consider whether the grounds upon which the previous decision rests would not be relevant for consideration in connection with the argument advanced by Mr. Sen. In so far as discharge of contract by reason of frustration is concerned there is no question of implying a term in the contract a term fundamental for its performance, as is done by the courts in England because we have here the provisions of s. 56 as well as those of s. 32 of the Contract Act. This is what was held by this Court in the earlier case and that decision binds us.
In our judgment the courts below were right in upholding the respondents claim.

edges.explanation: h2 elaborates on grounds for frustration including unlawfulness, addressing the core issue of discharge by frustration

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, a contract can be frustrated either because of supervening impossibility of performance or because performance has become unlawful by reason of circumstances for which neither of the parties was responsible. In the earlier case this Court has held that where the performance of an essential condition of the contract has become impossible due to supervening circumstances the contract would be discharged. This Court has further held that the impossibility need not be an absolute one but it is sufficient if further performance becomes impracticable by some cause for which neither of the parties was responsible. It, however, held that the mere fact that the performance of an essential term of the contract that is to say, of undertaking development of the area under the scheme could not be undertaken because the land had been requisitioned, did not have the effect of frustrating the contract.
In our judgment the courts below were right in upholding the respondents claim.
